update.description:
Add DEM support into Gazebo. You can load any raster DEM file, as long as it's supported by GDAL. GDAL will be an optional Gazebo library.

On Ubuntu Saucy, Raring or Quantal:
   
```
#!c++

sudo apt-get install gdal-bin libgdal-dev libgdal1 python-gdal
```
On Ubuntu Precise:
   
```
#!c++

sudo apt-get install gdal-bin libgdal1-1.7.0 libgdal1-dev python-gdal
```

It depends on [this sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/67/element-used-by-dem-heightmaps/diff).

**Example world**

The example world loads a heightmap from a GeoTiff file. If the SDF element *<size>* is present, the DEM will be loaded in scaled mode. Scaled mode means that the terrain will be scaled according to the *<size>* values. In non-scaled mode the terrain is loaded using its real dimensions.


```
#!c++

gazebo sdf/worlds/heightmap_dem.world

```

**Test**

Unit test for Dem, and integration test for checking that it's working with the GPS sensor.

**Coverage**

Dem.cc has 100% function coverage and 81% condition coverage.

**Tutorial**

There's a new [DEM tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/3.0/gazebo_dem) for Gazebo 3.0.
update.title: DEM support

content.raw: Thanks @caguero for taking care of all the issues. Looks good to me now. Again, impressive work, congrats!
content.html: Thanks @caguero for taking care of all the issues. Looks good to me now. Again, impressive work, congrats!

content.raw: @_jrivero_, thanks for taking the time to test it. The problem with high resolutions is due to the 64MB default protobuf max size as you probably know. I'd say that we can let it as it is and if there's enough interest inside the Gazebo community for working with high fidelity/resolution terrains, we can increase the limits or solve the problem in a different way.
content.html: @jrivero, thanks for taking the time to test it. The problem with high resolutions is due to the 64MB default protobuf max size as you probably know. I'd say that we can let it as it is and if there's enough interest inside the Gazebo community for working with high fidelity/resolution terrains, we can increase the limits or solve the problem in a different way.

content.raw: The limitation is still there for images but we decided not to raise an exception when this happens. I can work on a patch for using non squared images as heightmaps. Feel free to open a new ticket Jose.
content.html: The limitation is still there for images but we decided not to raise an exception when this happens. I can work on a patch for using non squared images as heightmaps. Feel free to open a new ticket Jose.

content.raw: sounds good. thanks.
content.html: sounds good. thanks.

content.raw: Good idea. Added in 389401c. Thanks Jose.
content.html: Good idea. Added in 389401c. Thanks Jose.

content.raw: It's expected. The expression calculates the number of height pixels in order to keep the original aspect ratio. I've added a comment in a2928c2.
content.html: It's expected. The expression calculates the number of height pixels in order to keep the original aspect ratio. I've added a comment in a2928c2.

content.raw: I've added a regular check instead of an assert in 261d66c. It's slower than an assert but more defensive and this method is only executed while loading the DEM file. Thanks for the suggestion Jose.
content.html: I've added a regular check instead of an assert in 261d66c. It's slower than an assert but more defensive and this method is only executed while loading the DEM file. Thanks for the suggestion Jose.

content.raw: Good idea. Checked in abb9023.
content.html: Good idea. Checked in abb9023.

content.raw: This is legacy code that I moved from HeightmapShape.cc . There are places where you multiply the image width by the subsampling value. I'd say that it's a good idea that the result of this operation returns a number of pixels (integer).
content.html: This is legacy code that I moved from HeightmapShape.cc . There are places where you multiply the image width by the subsampling value. I'd say that it's a good idea that the result of this operation returns a number of pixels (integer).

content.raw:
I did not find any major problem while testing.

I've changed a couple of details in the tutorial: the [order of the build instructions](http://gazebosim.org/w/index.php?title=Tutorials%2F3.0%2Fgazebo_dem&diff=5352&oldid=5323) and the use of a [tmp directory](http://gazebosim.org/w/index.php?title=Tutorials%2F3.0%2Fgazebo_dem&diff=5353&oldid=5352) so it the example can just work out of the box. We should think on mention the problem with the different versions the SSL curl for the people that plan on using this together with ROS packages.

For testing alternative cases, I've tried two examples:

* High resolution non square: gazebo is unable to start, with this log:
```
libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/io/coded_stream.cc:156] A protocol message was rejected because it was too big (more than 67108864 bytes).  To increase the limit (or to disable these warnings), see CodedInputStream::SetTotalBytesLimit() in google/protobuf/io/coded_stream.h.
libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/io/coded_stream.cc:156] A protocol message was rejected because it was too big (more than 67108864 bytes).  To increase the limit (or to disable these warnings), see CodedInputStream::SetTotalBytesLimit() in google/protobuf/io/coded_stream.h.
Exception [Heightmap.cc:348] Heightmap image size must be square, with a size of 2^n+1
```
* Non square small DEM file: seems to work, with the following result:

![dem file](https://photos-4.dropbox.com/t/0/AAAAaQiTJM4zZrVf9z7KFMDmqiykmRt32AaRlcWLUICYhQ/12/96660379/png/320x320/1/_/0/2/dem.png/1K5tkevvnYb35Vrn0FxVP0N1wPzSsl0t7XwbSoOai2Q)

Congrats, nice work!
content.html:
I did not find any major problem while testing.

I've changed a couple of details in the tutorial: the order of the build instructions and the use of a tmp directory so it the example can just work out of the box. We should think on mention the problem with the different versions the SSL curl for the people that plan on using this together with ROS packages.

For testing alternative cases, I've tried two examples:

  • High resolution non square: gazebo is unable to start, with this log:
libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/io/coded_stream.cc:156] A protocol message was rejected because it was too big (more than 67108864 bytes).  To increase the limit (or to disable these warnings), see CodedInputStream::SetTotalBytesLimit() in google/protobuf/io/coded_stream.h.
libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/io/coded_stream.cc:156] A protocol message was rejected because it was too big (more than 67108864 bytes).  To increase the limit (or to disable these warnings), see CodedInputStream::SetTotalBytesLimit() in google/protobuf/io/coded_stream.h.
Exception [Heightmap.cc:348] Heightmap image size must be square, with a size of 2^n+1
  • Non square small DEM file: seems to work, with the following result:

Congrats, nice work!

content.raw: Is the limitation about the square heightmaps not valid any more?
content.html: Is the limitation about the square heightmaps not valid any more?

content.raw: Looks like [RasterIO function](http://www.gdal.org/classGDALDataset.html#ae077c53268d2272eebed10b891a05743) return an error code (CE_Failure) or CE_None if all went just fine. In this case, could we check for this?
content.html: Looks like RasterIO function return an error code (CE_Failure) or CE_None if all went just fine. In this case, could we check for this?

content.raw: Could we add an assert for checking that nxSize and nYSize are greater than zero?
content.html: Could we add an assert for checking that nxSize and nYSize are greater than zero?

content.raw: This line is storing the result of a float division into an integer, with the corresponding lost of decimals. Is this expected? in that case, a comment could help here.
content.html: This line is storing the result of a float division into an integer, with the corresponding lost of decimals. Is this expected? in that case, a comment could help here.

content.raw: Could we add here some kind of safety checks to be sure that _subSampling is not zero? and probably not negative too.
content.html: Could we add here some kind of safety checks to be sure that _subSampling is not zero? and probably not negative too.

content.raw: Any reason not to declare _subSampling as double in the function parameters?
content.html: Any reason not to declare _subSampling as double in the function parameters?

On Ubuntu Saucy, Raring or Quantal:

content.raw: Good to know. Thanks Steve, merged.
content.html: Good to know. Thanks Steve, merged.

content.raw: Thanks for the suggestion Nate. Changed in 75a6b55.
content.html: Thanks for the suggestion Nate. Changed in 75a6b55.

content.raw: ImageHeightmap should not use multiple inheritance. An ImageHeightmap is not both an image and a heightmap data, it's a heightmap data object that happens to get it's information from an image. Composition is the better choice.
content.html: ImageHeightmap should not use multiple inheritance. An ImageHeightmap is not both an image and a heightmap data, it's a heightmap data object that happens to get it's information from an image. Composition is the better choice.

content.raw:
My mac has cppcheck 1.62, and it had a few comments about variable scoping in the FillHeightMap functions:
~~~
[gazebo/common/Dem.cc:246]: (style) The scope of the variable 'yf' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/Dem.cc:246]: (style) The scope of the variable 'dy' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/Dem.cc:247]: (style) The scope of the variable 'y1' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/Dem.cc:247]: (style) The scope of the variable 'y2' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/ImageHeightmap.cc:61]: (style) The scope of the variable 'yf' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/ImageHeightmap.cc:61]: (style) The scope of the variable 'dy' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/ImageHeightmap.cc:62]: (style) The scope of the variable 'y1' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/ImageHeightmap.cc:62]: (style) The scope of the variable 'y2' can be reduced.
~~~

I made an attempt at simplifying the scoping in 121b0d7, b43f655 (branch dem_support_scpeters) if you are interested.
content.html:
My mac has cppcheck 1.62, and it had a few comments about variable scoping in the FillHeightMap functions:

[gazebo/common/Dem.cc:246]: (style) The scope of the variable 'yf' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/Dem.cc:246]: (style) The scope of the variable 'dy' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/Dem.cc:247]: (style) The scope of the variable 'y1' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/Dem.cc:247]: (style) The scope of the variable 'y2' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/ImageHeightmap.cc:61]: (style) The scope of the variable 'yf' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/ImageHeightmap.cc:61]: (style) The scope of the variable 'dy' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/ImageHeightmap.cc:62]: (style) The scope of the variable 'y1' can be reduced.
[gazebo/common/ImageHeightmap.cc:62]: (style) The scope of the variable 'y2' can be reduced.

I made an attempt at simplifying the scoping in 121b0d7, b43f655 (branch dem_support_scpeters) if you are interested.

content.raw:
This makes totally sense. Specially because there's no reason for including FillHeightMap() and GetMaxElevation() in an Image class.

I have created a new ImageHeightmap class, and moved the heightmap-specific methods from Image to ImageHeightmap. There's a new unit test for this class too. This is done in 8c56e38.

Nate, I can imagine an overloaded constructor in HeightmapData that accepts an Image or an Dem. However, I cannot see a clean implementation of FillHeightMap(), GetHeight(), GetWidth() and GetMaxElevation() without checking the type of object that was used in the constructor.

Thanks for the suggestions.
content.html:
This makes totally sense. Specially because there's no reason for including FillHeightMap() and GetMaxElevation() in an Image class.

I have created a new ImageHeightmap class, and moved the heightmap-specific methods from Image to ImageHeightmap. There's a new unit test for this class too. This is done in 8c56e38.

Nate, I can imagine an overloaded constructor in HeightmapData that accepts an Image or an Dem. However, I cannot see a clean implementation of FillHeightMap(), GetHeight(), GetWidth() and GetMaxElevation() without checking the type of object that was used in the constructor.

Thanks for the suggestions.

Add DEM support into Gazebo. You can load any raster DEM file, as long as it's supported by GDAL. GDAL will be an optional Gazebo library.

On Ubuntu Saucy, Raring or Quantal:
   
```
#!c++

sudo apt-get install gdal-bin libgdal-dev libgdal1 python-gdal
```
On Ubuntu Precise:
   
```
#!c++

sudo apt-get install gdal-bin libgdal1-1.7.0 libgdal1-dev python-gdal
```

It depends on [this sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/67/element-used-by-dem-heightmaps/diff).

**Example world**

The example world loads a heightmap from a GeoTiff file. If the SDF element *<size>* is present, the DEM will be loaded in scaled mode. Scaled mode means that the terrain will be scaled according to the *<size>* values. In non-scaled mode the terrain is loaded using its real dimensions.


```
#!c++

gazebo sdf/worlds/heightmap_dem.world

```

**Test**

Unit test for Dem, and integration test for checking that it's working with the GPS sensor.

**Coverage**

Dem.cc has 100% function coverage and 81% condition coverage.

**Tutorial**

There's a new [DEM tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/3.0/gazebo_dem) for Gazebo 3.0.
update.title: DEM support

content.raw: gzerr and return false
content.html: gzerr and return false

content.raw: gzerr and return false.
content.html: gzerr and return false.

content.raw:
Use gzerr, and return false.

I'm would like to throw fewer exceptions, in favor of logging errors and letting the system continue. We should save gzthrow for truely system halting errors.
content.html:
Use gzerr, and return false.

I'm would like to throw fewer exceptions, in favor of logging errors and letting the system continue. We should save gzthrow for truely system halting errors.

content.raw:
It might be cleaner to make this function return true/false, and not throw an error. 

Consumers of this function can then test the return value instead of wrapping the code in a try/catch.
content.html:
It might be cleaner to make this function return true/false, and not throw an error.

Consumers of this function can then test the return value instead of wrapping the code in a try/catch.

content.raw: You're right. Thanks Ian. Fixed in 936f037.
content.html: You're right. Thanks Ian. Fixed in 936f037.
